bug.short_desc: Phoenix and Mozilla cannot comfortably share a source tree

long_desc.thetext:
The Mozilla build being used to file this identifies itself as Phoenix {Build ID: 2002081613}, it was built in a trunk source tree following a build of Phoenix earlier today
('Mozilla' built after following commands unset MOZ_PHOENIX, comment out mk_add_options MOZ_PHOENIX=1 in .mozconfig)
other symptoms: UI artefacts;
i navbar grippy lacks arrow ii Persbar lacks grippy

Created attachment 95592 comparison with same theme on 1.1b
additional UI artefact, new tab button disappearance

I have seen no such troubles building into separate objdirs from the same src tree, I assume you are building both on the src tree? Also, from reading your description, the attachment 95592 screenshot is Mozilla *2, right? Does the problem occur with modern and/or classic theme?

I expect it will affect Modern / Classic to an extent, but since it's my theme I *know* that the arrow is missing, because it is a separate image from the grippy background
This annoyance largely stems from laziness/impatience,
[user@host mozilla]$ make clean && make -f client.mk
tidies away the Phoenixisms, but given my comparatively low horsepower* PC I like to just use
[user@host mozilla]$ make -f client.mk
* 1200 Duron (up from 700 Celeron which is playing firewall, until I find something more sensible to do with it)

must have left something behind after make clean ... having changed another profile over to classic [by deleting chrome.rdf - because it started mozilla as a box asking what to do with navigator.xul] menubar has gone awol deleted chrome.rdf again; tacked skin,install,select,modern/1.0 on the end of installed-chrome.txt started with that profile again Modern has no menubar :?) it seems to affect different themes to different degrees, dependent on what is missing from the XUL ...

and of course a third profile exhibits different behaviour [still after make clean && make -f client.mk]
starting with "status quo" of profile set to Orbit 3+1, use View menu to set theme to classic, restart, get presented with save/open for navigator.xul, delete lock and chrome.rdf, restart, expect Mozilla - get save/open
end up using Mozilla 1.1b to set theme to classic, close 1.1b open trunk build with this profile, menubar is there
moral of this: don't underestimate the mess you can get into ; )
and of course this spam is not describing the complaint, which I'll have to test with Classic/Modern, when I build
export MOZ_PHOENIX=1 ; make -f client.mk (~/.mozconfig mk_add_options MOZ_PHOENIX=1)
unset MOZ_PHOENIX ; make -f client.mk (~/.mozconfig #mk_add_options MOZ_PHOENIX=1)
tomorrow BST [GMT+1]

Created attachment 95697 Latest post-Phoenix Mozilla build with Modern and Classic for comparison
The description probably should have been:
Phoenix and Mozilla cannot coexist in the same source tree.
i.e. One cannot expect to run Mozilla and Phoenix concurrently from the same dist/bin/ directory
random question: does deleting component.reg help?
random answer: there is no components.reg in dist/bin
Bryner, do we care? Is this easily fixed?

Bryner says we recommend objdir builds. There should be information on this available in the build newsgroup. A quick search through google groups turns up this thread http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&threadm=8c85a2%24bbb1%40secnews.netscape.com&rnum=1&prev=/groups%3Fhl%3Den%26lr%3D%26ie%3DUTF-8%26selm%3D8c85a2%2524bbb1%2540secnews.netscape.com but I'm not sure if that has sufficient information.
Not a bug. Resolving.
verified.

bug.short_desc: fix branding

long_desc.thetext: we need to fix the releaseURL, the about Phoenix and any other locations that still report Mozilla instead of Phoenix. This should happen for 0.1.

setting target. for the Releases link I guess we can just add <!ENTITY releaseURL "http://mozilla.org/projects/phoenix/releases.html"> to the browser.dtd. Do we need a brand.dtd and an about.dtd? can we combine a bunch of these?
*** Bug 167969 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
would fixing the userAgent to append Phoenix (ver) to the end be covered by this bug?
What say we replace Mozilla's crappy XHTML page-in-window (dialog in Phoenix) and add a /real/ about dialog, like, say, every other program on the planet?
Blake, we have a dialog. It already exists, we just need to flip the pref somewhere (all.js maybe?)
oops, misread. sure. let's for that, drop the contrib tab, make it a link in a single pane window.
new about dlg checked in, marking fixed.

"Other locations" would include about: (which still reports Mozilla, version 1.1b for me) and Themes ("Theme changes will take effect when youy restart Mozilla.").
Details of the latter are listed in duped bug 167969 (which is not fixed). The fix for that is to change brand.properties.
Also, about: could be fixed if about.xhtml was changed to use &brandShortName; and &lang.version; from brand.dtd.
Change about.xhtml's doctype as follows to allow the use of those entities:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.1//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11/DTD/xhtml11.dtd" [ <!ENTITY % brandDTD SYSTEM "chrome://global/locale/brand.dtd" > %brandDTD; ]>
-> Reopened Alternatively, we could mark this fixed (again) and reopen the duped bug to solve the Theme problem.

Appologies--forgot to mention that I verified the broken brand.properties in 2002-09-17-08.
Also, I see "Mozilla 0.1", not "Mozilla 1.1b" as previously stated (oops). It still says "Mozilla", though. (If making it import brand.dtd to use &brandShortName; is not desired, there's always the option of changing the hard-coded "Mozilla" in about.xhtml).
really fixed, I think.

verified. themes don't support us yet so we don't support them. panel and menu for switching removed. about dialog fixed. releases menulink fixed. Not sure what we're going to do about UA. This bug is finished though.

bug.short_desc: land pch's bookmarks patch from bug 160019

long_desc.thetext: We want bookmarks to not suck for Phoenix. Pierre is gonna help us with that :)
->pch

Created attachment 98344 Patch v1.0 for the mozilla trunk
Since nsIBookmarkService is not forked, I need few new methods. What this patch does is: - rename Create(Bookmark|Group|Folder)WithDetails into Create(...)InContainer to match what the methods do and their names ie inserting a new resource in the ds. - remove Create(Bookmark|Group|Folder) methods: only used in two places. They were creating a resource and appending it to the specified folder and were redundent with Create(...)WithDetails called with an index -1 - add Create(Bookmark|Group|Folder|Separator) methods: they create and return a resource but they do not insert it in the ds. These are the methods I need for the bookmark transaction manager. - fix a cpp warning: systemBookmarksURL is only used in the WIN or BeOS platform - fix a js warning (my bad) in bookmarksOverlay.js - fix a regression in navigatorDD.js: when dropping a item in the empty area of the personal toolbar, the feedback line was not removed.

Comment on attachment 98344 Patch v1.0 for the mozilla trunk
sr=hyatt
r/sr=blake

Comment on attachment 98344 Patch v1.0 for the mozilla trunk
>--- mozilla/xpfe/components/bookmarks/public/nsIBookmarksService.idl 1 Apr 2002 08:47:11 -0000 1.20 >+++ mozilla/xpfe/components/bookmarks/public/nsIBookmarksService.idl 8 Sep 2002 19:10:22 -0000 >@@ -56,17 +56,19 @@ > > void addBookmarkImmediately(in string aURI, in wstring aTitle, in long bmType, in wstring docCharset); > >- nsIRDFResource createFolder(in wstring aName, in nsIRDFResource aParentFolder); >- nsIRDFResource createFolderWithDetails(in wstring aName, in nsIRDFResource aParentFolder, >+ nsIRDFResource createFolder (in wstring aName); >+ nsIRDFResource createFolderInContainer(in wstring aName, in nsIRDFResource aParentFolder, > in long aIndex);
I think the general format we're using in this idl file is not to put extra space between the function name and the parameters.
>-NS_IMETHODIMP >-nsBookmarksService::CreateFolderWithDetails(const PRUnichar* aName, >+nsBookmarksService::CreateFolderInContainer(const PRUnichar* aName, > nsIRDFResource* aParentFolder, PRInt32 aIndex, > nsIRDFResource** aResult) > { >- return CreateFolderWithDetails(aName, aParentFolder, aIndex, aResult, PR_FALSE); >+ nsresult rv; >+ rv = CreateFolder(aName, aResult);
Just collapse this onto 1 line. Same thing several other places in this file.
>+ if (aIndex && aIndex >= 0)
Are you sure this condition is correct? At the very least, change >= to >, since it will always be false if aIndex == 0.

Created attachment 98649 Patch v1.1
I am a fool! I was asserting the folder group arc after that the resource were inserted in the ds. As a consequence, new groupmarks were appearing as folder. This patch corrects that and also fixes an another regression with the drag into folder feature (the personal toolbar submenu of the bookmark menu in the ptf may not close because its id is the same as the recently changed toolbar hbox one)
It includes bryner comments: when the argument is |null| or |undefined| in the js caller, aIndex is 0 in the cpp method. I then only have to check if aIndex<=0 to append it to the folder.

Comment on attachment 98649 Patch v1.1
I know the style in nsBookmarksService is kind of a mess, but in general I think we'd like C++ function names to start with a capital letter. Change insertResource to InsertResource and r/sr=bryner.

who.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext:
Comment on attachment 98649 Patch v1.1
r=ben@netscape.com

fixed. There is still work to do, I filed some bugs in the phoenix bookmark component, esp. bug 168410. I have modified the context menus by dropping items and changing some properties. This can be very easily modified.
landed indeed. verifying.

bug.short_desc: Extremely high memory consumption after closing all windows with Quick Launch (Turbo) enabled

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 20020907 (nightly downloaded a couple of minutes ago) OS: Win XP reproducible: always
If I close all open Phoenix windows and Quick Launch is enabled, the memory consumption of mozbrowser.exe goes from maybe 17MB to 140 odd MB within a couple of seconds. This makes the entire system highly unresponsive. It takes maybe ten to fifteen seconds for the memory consumption to come back down to 10-11 MB. This happens everytime I open a couple of windows and close them with Quick Launch enabled.
As a comparison, this behaviour is not displayed by Mozilla.
Steps to Reproduce: -------------------- 1. Enable Quick Launch in preferences 2. Open a window, navigate to some webpages 3. Close the open windows 4. Watch the memory consumption of mozbrowser.exe go through the ceiling
I don't get any cpu usage but quicklaunch doesn't seem to know the difference between mozilla.exe and mozbrowser.exe. Recommend we remove quicklaunch.
I don't get the CPU spike either, but the memory consumption seems to stall the remaining applications.
Memory consumption, I meant to say.
hmmm... maybe I had both mozilla and phoenix on at the same time. let me try killing one and seeing if that makes any difference at all.
quicklaunch is gone (as in, the UI to enable it is gone)
verified. there are no access points that I can find for quicklaunch code to be executed.

bug.short_desc: Bookmarks are not loaded if the Personal Toolbar is switched off

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20020921 Phoenix/0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20020921 Phoenix/0.1
If you disable the personal toolbar, the next time you start up with the Personal Toolbar disabled no bookmarks are avaiable.
The error;
bt.loadBookmarksCallback is not a function Source File: chrome://browser/content/browser.js Line: 347
is shown in the Javascript console. No bookmarks are displayed in the Bookmarks menu either.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Load Phoenix and disable the Personal Toolbar 2. Reload Phoenix 3. Re-enable the Personal Toolbar.
Actual Results: The Personal Toolbar will be empty, and the Bookmarks menu will only display Add to Bookmarks... and Manage Bookmarks... menu items. If you use the Manage menu item you will see all your bookmarks are still in place.
Expected Results: The Bookmarks should be loaded whether the Personal Toolbar is enabled or not.

Yes, I've been bothered by this for a while, too. I think this is introduced some time between Sep. 12 and 16. (The 0912 build doesn't have this problem, and 0916 has this. I didn't download the builds in between.)
I've also found a work-around: open a second window and the bookmarks will be there...
Btw, I'm using Linux builds.

bug.short_desc: "mozbrowser" script doesn't start correct binary

It's obviously a no-op for normal Mozilla builds.

bug.short_desc: pheonix

long_desc.thetext:
This is a very interesting post from slashdot that you should consider:
Stupid to change the name (Score:0) by Anonymous Coward on Tuesday September 24, @01:38PM (#4320540) Don't these guys understand the importance of brand rocognition? Releasing a browser with a totally unrelated name really just muddies the waters. It should just be called Mozilla Lite or something so that if people discover and like it then it will expand the mozilla mindshare, not fragment it.
Get a clue moz people! [ Reply to This | Parent ]

Thank you. Post considered.
This isn't mozilla lite. Mozilla is a big, bloated suite. This is a standalone browser.

verified.
In the future please do not file issues which are not bugs. Thanks for your interest in Phoenix.

bug.short_desc: Please tell people to use a new profile.

long_desc.thetext:
I ran phoenix with an old profile, then ran it with a new one I created in the profile manager when Phoenix started. It made a difference which profile I used. I think people should be told about this on the "Installation Notes" on http://www.mozilla.org/projects/phoenix/phoenix-release-notes.html
Suggested entry:
To use Phoenix properly, create a new profile for it in the Profile Manager. It will not work as it is meant to with a profile for the standard version of Mozilla.
This is not a bug. Phoenix creates a Phoenix profile on first run. There is no user intervention beyond that.
It didn't for me. I already have two profiles on my computer and therefore it brought up profile manager.

netdemon, Phoenix does not create multiple profiles, the user does. If you figured out how to create multiple profiles using a command line option then you can very well figure out how to create a new one if you've got problems with an old one. Do not reopen this bug.

My mistake. When I unpacked Phoenix, I accidentally dragged the Mozilla binaries into that directory. Therefore, I was running Mozilla, and thought it was Phoenix. No wonder it looked almost the same. :-)

bug.short_desc: Scroll bar becomes blank

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20020924 Phoenix/0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20020924 Phoenix/0.1
When you scroll a long page the scroll bar glyphs (up/down arrow and the "thumb" texture) slide off to the right, leaving the scroll bar blank.
Reproducible: Always

Wayne, bugs which are about page layout are generally not Phoenix bugs. Phoenix utilizes the Mozilla layout code. Bugs you see with web content are going to overwhelmingly be Mozilla bugs.
Doing a query for bugs with cnn.com in the url would have turned up bug 169620 and its 23 duplicate reports. With a bug this obvious it is very likely that it is already reported. In this case the bug has accumulated 23 (now 24) duplicate reports in the week since it was introduced. Please take the time to look for existing reports so we can focus our time on fixing bugs or finding new ones rather than resolving duplicates. Thanks for your help in testing Phoenix and reporting bugs.

User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20020924 Phoenix/0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20020924 Phoenix/0.1

Created attachment 100649 Hitting Enter should activate the "Find Next" button
This bug isn't specific to a particular web page. It has to do with the button focus in the Find dialog. In this image, notice that the Wrap checkbox is the active control, and that the "default" highlight is on the Find Next button.
If you hit Enter, it should behave as though you clicked Find Next. Instead, hitting Enter does nothing.

bug.short_desc: Browser is ignoring the attibute TITLE in TAG <img...

that's not a TITLE, that's an ALT and we're not ignoring it. we're doing what's expected and displaying the alt text when images aren't available. if you want that text in a title tip then you need to put a title attribute in there in addition to an alt attribute.

thanks and nice work.
brendan hinkle
configure them in to do ctrl+left arrow and ctrl+right arrow.

Asa, this is a RFE about adding support for the window messages that the mouse button click sends. The reporter knows that it can be configured using IntelliPoint, but it requires software to run (POINT32.EXE). IE and Netscape supports these window messages directly, without point32.exe running.
This should be as simple as listening for clicks on mouse buttons 4 and 5. Hope this helps.

bug.short_desc: network.cookie.enableForCurrentSessionOnly doesn't work

long_desc.thetext:
Using the current CVS code.
Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to preferences, enable cookies and enable for the current session options. 2. Remove All Cookies. 2. Go to a site that sets persistant cookies (e.g. www.cnn.com). 3. Exit Phoenix. 4. Start Phoenix and notice that there are cookies present.
I only have the two cookie related prefs in my prefs.js file:
user_pref("network.cookie.enableForCurrentSessionOnly", true); user_pref("network.cookie.enableForOriginatingWebsiteOnly", true);
Since this is a major regression and the fix is so simple, nominating for 0.4.
It's not really a "regression" since I was fixing/implementing this among other cookie prefs, but thanks -- I'll look into it.

> It's not really a "regression" since I was > fixing/implementing this among other > cookie prefs, but thanks -- I'll look into it.
The loss of "current session only cookies" functionality is the regression from prior versions of Phoenix, not the code change itself.
Prior to the Oct 19th check-in, it was possible to have all cookies expire at the end of the session, using the Mozilla-style cookie prefs. After Oct 19th, there is no way to limit the cookie lifetime to the current session.
--> me
Fixed.
Verified in 20021029 nightly.

(no debugging symbols found)...(no debugging symbols found)... (no debugging symbols found)...(no debugging symbols found)...
(no debugging symbols found)...(no debugging symbols found)...[New Thread 2049 (LWP 22940)] [New Thread 1026 (LWP 22941)] [New Thread 2051 (LWP 22942)] [New Thread 3076 (LWP 22943)] [New Thread 4101 (LWP 22944)]
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault. [Switching to Thread 1024 (LWP 22938)] 0x40c92f7e in NSGetModule () from /opt/phoenix/components/libwidget_gtk.so (gdb) (gdb) step Single stepping until exit from function NSGetModule, which has no line number information. Cannot find user-level thread for LWP 22941: generic error (gdb)
What's different about the two machines?

Well, the linux distribution is the same on both machines. It is Sourcemage, which is source based (I use gcc 2.95.3)
I have put the lists of installed packages on both machines at http://benatoll.free.fr/working_install.txt http://benatoll.free.fr/failing_install.txt
The pc on which phoenix works has an amd K6 450, ati rageIIc The other is a thinkpad 390X laptop with a PII 400 (mozilla works fine on it)
Is there a way to check my system ? (Seems I'm alone with that bug so it's probable the fault is due to my system) Is there any lib that could be re-built (just to be sure there's a clean ground) ?
Have you tried 0.3 or newer installed into a clean directory and started with a new profile?

Yes, it's still the same problem with the 0.3 tarball
Fortunately, I've succeeded building it from cvs and it works this way.

Well, those boxes not really that close if you diff those two files. For one, you have different glibc:
-glibc:20020927:installed:2.2.5 +glibc:20021008:installed:2.2.5
Shouldn't matter much, but is it too much to ask of you to do a re-installation of the failing box to see if it was a system error? It certainly looks like it.

Well, I anticipated your question, I have already re-installed my system and I'm now using the 0.4 phoenix binary which works very well.
So yes, there was something wrong with my system, seems like we'll never know what ... (the glibc were the same, just installed at different dates)
Thanks for testing this Mikael. Resolving as WORKSFORME then.

bug.short_desc: Two oddities in Print Preview

long_desc.thetext:
#1. I use Phoenix on 2 computers. One has a 1024 x 768 screen resolution. The other can't do better than 800 x 600. In the "print preview" mode on the 1024 x 768 screen, there is a "close" button at the upper right. But on the 800 x 600 computer, the word "landscape" extends to the upper right corner and there is no "close" button.
#2. On both computers, Ctl-W and Alt-F4 have counter-intuitive effects. In all other multi-window situations, Ctl-W closes only the current window and Alt-F4 exits Phoenix completely. In a Print Preview, the effects are 100 percent reversed: Alt-F4 closes the preview and returns to normal browse view, while Ctl-W unexpectedly exits Phoenix completely.
Confirming #2.

Reporter: Please have just one issue per bug. Also please remember to include the build id in your bug reports. Please read the bug reporting guidelines: http://www.mozilla.org/quality/bug-writing-guidelines.html
I considered the two oddities to be one issue because both apply to the "print preview" screen. (However, I can see your point that perhaps I should have reported them separately.)

>> Also please remember to include the build id in your bug reports.
Not always as easy as it sounds. Normally the build info should be available in the help/about window. But I used uabar to change the ua string, then downloaded a new nightly, and did not reinstall uabar. Guess what shows up in help/about now. It is not the correct build info for the new nightly.

If you cannot get the exact build id, please at least write the date you downloaded the build.
I suggest you resolve this bug as invalid, and open two new bugs, one for each issue, using the bugzilla helper: http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/enter_bug.cgi?format=guided
Thanks.
Will resubmit as 2 bugs per Lasse's request.

Thanks Neil.
Verified.

  • s gives me a headache. possibly helpful code: ________________________________________________________________________________ Effecting site: http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=KB;EN-US;Q279157& Q279157 - Description of CD-ROM Recording in Windows XP
      All Products  |  Support  |  Search  |  Microsoft.com Guide
      Home     FAQs     Downloads     Newsgroups     Customer Service     Contact Us  
      Send     Help   
    Product Support Centers

    Contact Microsoft

    Customer Services
    Customer Care, Product Purchasing, Site and Production Information
    Newsgroups
    Pose a question to other users. Discussion groups and Forums about specific Microsoft products, technologies, and services.
    Microsoft Knowledge Base Article - Q279157

    Description of CD-ROM Recording in Windows XP

    The information in this article applies to:
    • Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition
    • Microsoft Windows XP Professional

    SUMMARY

    This article describes the functionality of the CD recorder feature. When you use Windows XP, you can write data to a CD-R, or write and rewrite data to a CD-RW. In addition, you can erase data from a CD-RW, but not from a CD-R.

    MORE INFORMATION

    Support for the International Standards Organization (ISO) Image

    The CD-RW recording feature that is built in to the Windows XP shell does not support the creation of an International Standards Organization (ISO) image. To create an ISO image in Windows XP, you need to install a third party utility that supports this feature.

    An ISO image file is a snapshot of the data and layout of a CD-ROM, saved in ISO-9660 format. ISO image files are widely used for storing CD content. ISO is a common CD image format for DOS, Windows (Joliet ISO extension), Linux (RockRidge ISO extension), and other operating systems.

    Description of the Staging Area

    To facilitate CD recording, Windows XP uses a staging area to store the data for recording, which is located in the following hidden folder:
      Drive_letter:\Documents and Settings\username\Local Settings\Application Data\Microsoft\CD Burning
    In addition, the information in the staging area is copied to a monolithic disc image file before you record the data. By default, this file is named "Cd burning stash file.bin" and is located in the root folder. You can change the location of the file in the CD recorder Properties dialog box.

    How to Move Files to the Staging Area

    There are four methods that you can use to copy files to the staging area:
    • Method 1: You can use a drag-and-drop operation to move the files to the CD burner icon.
    • Method 2: Right-click the file (or files), click Send To, and then click Name or Drive Letter of your Writable CD.
    • Method 3: Click the file, click Send To on the File menu, and then click Name or Drive Letter of your Writable CD.
    • Method 4: Copy the files manually to the staging area.

    How to Initiate the Burn Process

    There are two methods to start the burn process after the files are in the staging area:
    • Method 1: Under CD Writing Tasks, click Write these files to CD.
    • Method 2: Right-click the CD drive, and then click Write these files to CD.

bug.short_desc: Phoenix crashes on startup even after removing profile

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021016 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021016
I've been trying Phoenix builds from pre 0.4 and they're all crashing on startup. I've removed my .phoenix dir, and installed in a clean dir, but the problem remains. I briefly see a window with no contents, and then it dissappears. There is no error message given on the commandline. I've tried running with -ProfileManager too, but that crashes aswell.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run ./phoenix in phoenix directory.
Actual Results: Phoenix crashed with no error message.
Expected Results: Err, not crashed? ;)

You did not specify how new a build you have tried. Have you tried the nightly builds at http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/phoenix/nightly/2002-11-09-08-trunk/ ?
If not, please try those and report back what happens. Also, do you have some GTK theme installed?
This is not a blocker.

It was a fairly recent build, but I've just tried that build and it done the same. I did have a gtk theme installed, so I moved the .gtkrc and now it works. And now I've moved it back again it still seems to work. It's my own hack of a theme so maybe something upset it, I'm not sure. Working now though, so I'll set to worksforme.
With regards to being a blocker, when I filled the form in, blocker was defined as stopping me using or developing mozilla. Since I couldn't even start it, I assumed this was the correct option. Apologies if it wasn't.

bug.short_desc: Nothing works - phoenix starts normally but no commands do anything

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 Galeon/1.2.6 (X11; Linux i686; U;) Gecko/20020827 Build Identifier: Phoenix 0.4 or latest nightly
I'm probably being very stupid, so when I:
cd tar -xzf phoenix-i686-pc-linux-gnu.tar.gz rm -rf .phoenix cd phoenix ./phoenix
I get a correct-looking phoenix window, but then nothing seems to work. I can type in the location bar, but nothing happens when I press enter. I can select various things from the menu, but none of them seem to do anything. File -> Close doesn't do anything, but File->Quit does quit phoenix. There are no debugging messages or any errors signaled.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.explained above 2. 3.
Actual Results: Something happens
Expected Results: Nothing happens
Redhat 7.2
I think this is a latest-nightly problem (bug).. try older build
Yes, you are right. I thought I had tried 0.4, but apparently not. 0.4 works fine for me.
This has been fixed. Resolving as WORKSFORME. Please reopen if you still see it with a recent nightly build.

bug.short_desc: some blocked pop-ups don't register - pop up blocking needs manual adding to whitelist

long_desc.thetext: Currently pop-up blocking (when turned on) shows a yellow (i) button on status bar, which allows you to add that site to the pop-up whitelist. However, when using the web end of an exchange e-mail server, with po-up blocking on alot of functionality is lost, and the way in which it works (I think) prevents the yellow icon appearing. reading an e-mail seems ok, but to reply, the site closes the current window, and tries to open a new window - presumably as an action of closing the previous one. This fails, and there is no yellow (i) on the original root window - and the closed window.. is obviously closed. It would be nice if in the prefs there was a way to manually add to the whitelist. Possible would also be to turn off blocking, visit the site again, and when the pop-ups occur, to have the yellow (i) appear _anyway_ and let sites be added to the whitelist _even_ when pop-up blocking is not enabled. (this does not sound like an ideal solution to me - but more user friendly than manually adding sites.) If anything, I'd like to know if I can manually add the site in a pref file to solve my own immediate issue. But still think this is a bug, some pop-ups don't register with the pop-up blocker ui. The code onthe site for the reply button is: which refers to: if (szCommand == "reply") { window.location="commands.asp?command=reply&obj=00000000178F4CA9ECC5D41183E000D0B7D3010807009D10E7EFC779D411B03400D0B7D301080000000C14B500009D10E7EFC779D411B03400D0B7D30108000001DDDED70000"; } in this instance..

I can't confirm or disconfirm the non-registering part of the bug, but you can edit cookperm.txt to add individual sites.
exchange-server.com 2F
I think that's the correct format to allow popups.
worksforme with 1026 build.

asa: when you say that it works for you, have you tried this on an Outlook Web Access site? I just tried it aghain with a brand new install (Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021026 Phoenix/0.3) and the Outlook Web Access site was the first one I visited with a pop-up. I obtained the initial phoenix warning re popups, and how a status bar icon would be shown. However such an icon was not shown. So this doesn't work when the winow to be opened originates from a window that is closed. Also there is no way to manually add a site to the pop-up whitelist from the GUI. _I_ am happy with the workaround of manually editing cookperm.txt, but this isn't a valid solution to the bug.

With the new 'add site' button, I think this bug counts as fixed, rather than WFM, as the bug report calls for such an ability to over come a problem. However, as it now does technically work for me.. due to the new button which I regard as a fix, I shall simply verify.

bug.short_desc: fullscreen: WM titlebar still visible (possible regression)

long_desc.thetext:
Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021111 Phoenix/0.4
with both new and old profiles on a Debian 3.0 box running KDE 2.2.2 as the window manager (WM). When pressing F11 to go to fullscreen mode KDE's titlebar is still visible, whereas before (0.4 final and earlier) it went to a true fullscreen. By all reports this seems to be Linux-only right now, although I would like to have a Red Hat or other non-Debian Linux user confirm this as well.
See bug 174175
Does this occur in the latest Mozilla nightly too?

Oops. Yes, it's a Mozilla problem. Phoenix is having so many fullscreen problems of its own that I thought this was just another one. I've even found a dupe for it, bug 179043
-->Duping my own bug
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 179043 ***

bug.short_desc: cache not working efficiently ?

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.1) Gecko/20020826 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.1) Gecko/20020826
When opening a page in phoenix with a lot of images, following a link, then clicking 'back' to get back the the high image-density page seems to indicate that the cache isn't being used effectively. The images always seem to load again, very slowly. See lots of time waiting for page to re-populate.
This, of course, doesnt sound like a phoenix bug - but rather existing in the moz codebase. Thing is that mozilla (M1.1) has no problem in this area. Returning to a high image-density page sees them loaded instantaneously - no latency at all indicating that the cache is working fine.
Problem only exists in phoenix.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Open high image-density page 2. follow a link forwards 3. click 'back' to return to page 4. images appear to be loaded from scratch again.

Reporter, you're using a 2.5 months old build. Things have changed a lot since then.
Personally, with 20021111, I don't see any of the problems you mentionned.
Please, update to a newer build (with a new profile) and reopen this bug if you still see the problem. Verify that your disk cache is not empty as well (the default setting should work fine).
Resolving as WORKSFORME

Marc: uh, I'm reporting the bug using M1.1 which is 4 months old. The bug report is about Phoenix, not 1.1
My phoenix agent is: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4 (Sorry, this was omitted from the bug report)
Installation was installed with a new profile.

bug.short_desc: Secured site icon hides blocks window pop-up icon

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; WinNT4.0; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; WinNT4.0; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4
Browsing to a secured site shows the lock-pad icon at the same location as the blocked windows pop-up icon, hiding it from view. Since I use pop-up blocking, I did not get any visual prompt from a secure site that poped-up an installation applet, leading me to think that the secured site is unresponsive.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. 2. 3.
Actual Results: No window pop-up alert indication
Expected Results: To show both secured site lock-pad icon and pop-up alert icon at different location.
You should provide a link to a site that shows this problem.

I have tried to keep my comment general due to the complexity of the site. Anyway, it was realized at https://us.webex.com/webexdemos/site/advancedframe.php?Rnd9990=0.7362143512126356
But you need to register for the demo web-meeting, and when the meeting starts you should join in. The site will then try to download 2MB+ meeting manager to your computer.

I haven't yet found a secure site that also throws *unwanted* pop-ups around [which is a *good* thing as far as I'm concerned] but the pop-up alert and secure site icons do occupy the same space on the status bar so the possibility is certainly there.

I am not taking about an unwanted pop-up. In this case it was a registration pop-up, mandatory for site usage, but I never knew that there was a reg pop-up because the "i" icon was covered by the pad lock icon.
Works for me on https://shockplay.com/ Reporter, the i icon is shown only when a page tries to load *unwanted* popups. I've tried the webex site, but saw no pop-up, even in MSIE6.

Ok, we seem to have concluded that *in this case* there was no pop-up icon along with a secured site icon, but the issue remains however:
Do the secure site icon and the pop-up 'i' icon occupy the same space on the status bar when going to an https site that throws up unrequested pop-ups, and, if so, which trumps which? I would dearly hope that no webmaster would ever construct a secure site with unrequested pop-ups but we should at least consider the possibility.
I, for one, would be happier if the icons occupied adjacent spaces on the status bar as that would cover any possibility.

David, if you go to to https://shockplay.com/ (secure site with unrequested popup, yes), you'll see this in the left of your statusbar: http://images.delahaye.net/shockplay.png As you can see, the icons are *already* adjacent.

bug.short_desc: wrong Version reported in Windows "Properties" dialog box

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4

Generally, keyboard shortcuts with other keys than A-Z, 0-9 should be avoided.

bug.short_desc: Popup blocking ignores javascript window open commands for sites in the accept list

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.2b) Gecko/20021029 Phoenix/0.4
Clicking on a link that uses javascript to open a new window fails when the following preferences are set:
(X) Reject Popup windows
and the domain (www.vtsportbike.net) is added into the accept list.
Disabling the popup blocking causes the link to function correctly.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to provided url. 2. Enable popup blocking 3. Add (www.vtsportbike.net) to accept list 4. Click 'Test Link' 5. No window opens. 6. Dispable popup blocking 7. Click link. 8. Window popus up.
Actual Results: Nothing happens.
Also, the little 'I' in the bottom left corner does not show to indicate a popup has been blocked.
Expected Results: Should have opened a smaller window. The page results in a 404, but that's expected.

Phoenix popup blocking feature only blocks popups that the user never requested (ie. popups that try to open themselves on load or on unload of the page). "Normal "popups aren't blocked.
That said, your page WFM with Phoenix 20021119 on w2k. Could you please try with a recent build and a new profile?

bug.short_desc: Large icons become small icons when new window is opened

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021128 Phoenix/0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021128 Phoenix/0.4
Large icons become small icons when new window is opened. Also, if there is a distinct background associated with small icons, that background will appear as well.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. On any theme, set View > Toolbars > Customize to large icons (uncheck the small icons box. 2. Open a new window (either with mouse gestures or File > New Window or Ctrl-n).
Actual Results: The new window will have small icons. If there is a distinctive background associated with small icons, that background will also appear (see, e.g. the theme MZ, which has a soft green background with large icons and a silver background with small icons).
Expected Results: The new window should have whatever setting the original window had.

I would like to withdraw this bug. After I wiped out my old profile and rebuilt with a clean one, this problem disappeared. I've had this problem before, but until it crops up again and I can nail it down better, I don't think it's ripe for consideration.

bug.short_desc: Can't duplicate bookmark items in the same folder

It's nice that I can't dupe it, but a bit surprising when I forget there is another identical entry in somewhere in the same folder. How about "it's dupe" dialog if it's WONTFIX?

It's not a bug, if Phoenix doesn't allow the duplication of bookmark entries in the same folder, it's a feature, because it also ensures, that you don't bookmark the same site more than once by mistake.
I'm resolving this as INVALID. If you want a error message to come up, every time someone tries to add a duplicate of a bookmark entry, file a separate enhancement bug.

bug.short_desc: Select User dialog box shows a duplicated user when only one has ever been entered

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021210 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021210 Phoenix/0.5
I am behind a company firewall. To access the internet I have to set up an "Automatic proxy configuration URL:" via Tools > Preferences > Connection.
When I first access the internet I am prompted with a "login box" for my firewall's proxy where I need to enter my name, password, and whether I want the values saved in my password list. I put a checkmark next to "save values in my password list". At this point I surf the web happily.
Next time I start the browser and choose to surf the web, before I am prompted with a login box for my firewall's proxy I am prompted with a dialog box requesting that I "select a username to be entered on this form.". The two usernames it has for me to select are identical and both are the name I entered previously. I can select either one of the names and the correct values show up in the login box for my firewall's proxy and I surf happily.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. With a fresh install of Phoenix (no old version of phoenix installed) I go to "Tools > Preferences... > Connection > Automatic proxy configuration URL:" and I enter the URL of my company's web proxy. 2. Click the OK button to close the Preferences dialog box. 3. Enter any URL into the Navigation toolbar and press enter. 4. I am prompted with a dialog box asking for my name and password (for my company's web proxy) and whether I want to save the information in my password list. I enter my name, password, and that YES I do want to save the information in my password list. I press enter. 5. I surf the web happily and close the browser down. 6. Restart Phoenix. Type a URL into the navigation toolbar. Actual Results: Instead of getting the dialog box for the proxy, I get a dialog box asking me to "select a username to be entered on this form." The two usernames it has for me to choose are identical to the username I entered into the proxy dialog box the first time I used Phoenix (in step 4 above).
Expected Results: I should not be prompted to "select a username to be entered on this form". I should go directly to the dialog box asking for my name and password (step 4 above) with my previously entered values filled in.
Also, I never entered in any different login to my company's proxy (only did step 4 above once), so the "select a username to be entered on this form" dialog box should only contain one name to choose, not two.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 184857 ***
v.

bug.short_desc: 'close sidebar' icon/button/image is vertically squashed by a few pixels

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021116 Phoenix/0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021116 Phoenix/0.4
The small (x) button or icon on the Sidebar is apparently the same as the one used at the far right of the window tabs but is not the same height. I don't know anything about the UI language used, but if it were HTML I would say the HEIGHT attribute is too small by about 5 pixels.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Open the Sidebar by any method to any pane, using the default theme. 2.Open multiple tabs to any webpage (or none) by any method. 3.Compare the close button at the top right of the Sidebar and the close button at the far right of the tabs, which closes the current tab.
Actual Results: The close-current-tab button looks round, and the close-sidebar one looks vertically compressed. I am going to attach a screenshot of this.
Expected Results: Several possible solutions:
1. use the same image but scale it down both vertically & horizontally for the Sidebar so it stays round.
2. Use a smaller image for the Sidebar than for the close-current-tab button.
3. Reduce the vertical height of the tabs, and use a smaller image in both places. I notice that the same font is used in both places (sidebar heading and tab title), but there is more vertical space above and below the image in the tab area; the tabs themselves have more vertical space below the page title and favicon. If this is not thought to be necessary, it could be reduced and a smaller button/icon/image could be used in both places.
I cannot test this with a different theme cuz I can't get any to work -- I assume this is a known issue or I am a known idiot.
I am on redhat 7.3 using Fluxbox.
Should there be a bug category for Sidebar issues? I looked and it seems that these bugs get filed a variety of places, when they might fit into such a category better.

Created attachment 106532 both buttons for comparison
THis shows the buttons mentioned.

This issue has been known for quite a while but I don't think anyone has filed a bug on it. No one seems to know what caused it either and it will probably be fixed when a new default theme is selected. Most other themes fix this problem... but apparently you can't get any to work (please visit the Phoenix Forums and describe your theme install problem in the Themes topic area). Toolbars really isn't the right component so I'm forking it to General.
-->Component: General -->All OS -->Marking as New

bug.short_desc: behaviour inconsistent with Mozilla 1.2.1 when accessing https:// site with badly named certificate

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
When I go to https://mysite.com in Phoenix I get an Alert box which says "Error establishing encrypted connection to mysite.com. Error code -8054"
When I do the same thing in Mozilla 1.2.1 I get a message box "Website Certified by Unknown Authority" which allows me to accept the certificate. If I accept it I then get a second error box "Security Error - Domain Name Mismatch" which warns me that the name on the certificate is "localhost" while the site name is "mysite.com". I can blow past that error as well and eventually get in to the site.
Yeah, I know I have set up lame certificates on this Apache box, but still - Phoenix ought to handle it the same way that Mozilla does, no?
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. As above... 2. 3.
Actual Results: I got the error
Expected Results: Phoenix and Mozilla should present consistent dialogs when presented with the same conditions.
I love Phoenix. It is great. Please fix it. It is a pain in the ass to have to use two browsers.

This is WFM using Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021213 Phoenix/0.5 Reporter, could you please try with a recent nightly and a new profile? You can learn more about that here: http://texturizer.net/phoenix/bugs.html
I guess your bug was caused by a server problem.

Via email (please don't! use bugzilla to add comments): ----- I'll try to do this with a more recent nightly and a new profile. Unfortunately I am using P-0.5 as my main browser (it is great) and so I don't want to uninstall it.
You are correct. The root cause of this is that I have a couple of lame certificates on my servers, which may be more common that not - I can't be the only semi-competent server admin out there - but as I say, I would expect that Phoenix and Mozilla would at least fail gracefully in the same way, since Phoenix is not a code fork but is built on the main branch of Mozilla, no?
I will re-report when I've done this. -----
This works in current phoenix linux builds

bug.short_desc: [split] autocomplete shows credit card numbers when only the first number is typed

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win 9x 4.90; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030105 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win 9x 4.90; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030105 Phoenix/0.5
Autocomplete seems to collect information that users may not want collected, even down to incorrectly typed URL's, and incorrectly entered user-name/password details, but what is worse, it collects credit card numbers, and other "sensitive" data, and displays them whenever a number is typed, as long as the number entered is the first number of the series. OK so autocomplete can be turned off, not that your everday user knows where to find their profile, and then knows to create a user.js file. But even with autocomplete turned off, does it continue to secretly squirrel away information in the event of being turned on again. It would seem a lot of information is collected with the everyday user having no idea how to edit this info, even down to Download manager continuing to collect download info which it is unable to delete simply because there is no apparent way of finding it. Anyone with the knowledge of where these details are stored and how to access it, can use this information even when they do not have the authority, simply because the average user has no idea on the internal workings of Mozilla, and Phoenix.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. details above should be self explanatary 2. 3.
Expected Results: able to edit autocomplete, or have the ability to determine what information is collected, or turn autocomplete off, and have no information collected at all.
There appears to be no level of severity to cover the loss/misuse of sensitive personal data.

There are way too many issues covered by this bug.
1. Don't autocomplete incorrect urls: bug 66049.
2. Ability to delete incorrect passwords: bug 173565 (replace password manager with satchel), bug 104436 (delete a username/password in prompt to choose between several u/p combinations), bug 157752.
3. Ability to delete autocomplete entries: bug 171605 (phoenix), bug 157749 (mozilla).
4. "It would seem a lot of information is collected with the everyday user having no idea how to edit this info, even down to Download manager continuing to collect download info which it is unable to delete simply because there is no apparent way of finding it." I'm not sure what you mean.
5. Ability to determine what information form autocomplete has collected (so that someone else who uses your computer and knows the autocomplete file format doesn't have more control than you): I don't know if there's a bug for this. Please file one.
6. Pref to turn form autocomplete off: I don't see a bug for this. Please file one.
7. Avoid storing things that look like credit card numbers: I don't see a bug for this. Please file one. (Maybe form auto complete should leave out entries containing only digits, spaces, and hyphens. See also bug 46590, "insecure submit of credit card # should warn user even if insecure submit warning turned off".)
When you file bugs for 5, 6, and 7, please post the bug numbers here to make it easier to verify this bug.
verified

Sorry, the thing about download manager was as a result of me finding a file which appears to contain details of every download I have made since installing Phoenix 0.5, even though my preference is for a progress window. This is an unnecessary waste of space, and there should be a way of deleting this information; after all how many users would know it was there, even if they wanted to access this information.
Also refer bugs:
5:- 188282; 6:- 188283; 7:- 188285

Thanks for splitting up the bugs. If you want to file a bug (or several bugs) about the download manager as well, go ahead, but please make sure the bugs you report are specific. It's much easier to track which bugs are fixed, etc. when each bug report covers exactly one issue.
Sorry again. By selecting the preference to have the download sidebar open, all previously completed downloads are displayed, and hence can be deleted. I should have used it before, but never did.

My preferences has freezed after instalation of Macromedia shockplayer. When I has removed macromedia plugin (NPSWF32.dll) from phonix\plugins directory, Phonexi still freeze. CPU load of Phonix doesn't change when is freezed.
Best, hide

bug.short_desc: Opening second window, cannot type in text boxes or address/search bar

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030117 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030117 Phoenix/0.5
When I open a second browser window or I get a popup and try to type in a text box, copy and paste a URL or search on google from the address bar, the text won't type in. Copy and paste doesn't work either. It's like the second window doesn't know that the keyboard is attached
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Phoenix 2. hit "Ctrl + n" 3. try to type in a URL in the address box
Actual Results: no text showed up
Expected Results: typed http://www.mozilla.org in the address URL box
My pc, Win XP pro sp1, IE6.0sp1, Gecko/20030117, Mozilla 1.3,
This has happened to me since Ver 0.5 came out
Completely delete your old install folder. Get a new nightly build. Delete your old profile and start clean. If this is still a problem reopen.

bug.short_desc: Page comes up blank in Phoenix 2003-01-08, AOK in 0.5 release

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win 9x 4.90; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Phoenix 0.5 build 1/8/03
In Phoenix 0.5, this URL and many others like it in some way, on this web site and others including the one at my bank, comes up perfectly; but in the 1/8/03 nightly Phoenix, it and the others come up blank. It's utterly repeatable, and it happens independently of JavaScript and window-suppression settings et al.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to < http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/world/ >. 2. Observe.
Actual Results: Blank screen.
Expected Results: Shown page.
wfm Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030108 Phoenix/0.5

Works for me 20030110 Linux
I get a form fill-in screen asking me to fill out details, including, for some peculiar reason, a zip code...
Try using a new profile for the later release.
note: please use the ISO date format when specifying a release. 1/8/03 is non-standard and confusing whereas 2003-01-08 is unambiguous. Given the pace at which Phoenix is progressing right now, it may well be August before anything gets done on bugs filed right now, at which point 1/8/03 is going to cause confusion problems...
worksforme with builds from this morning.

bug.short_desc: Browser crashes when logging in to t-mobile.com

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Its pretty simple.
1. Put in username. 2. Put in password. 3. Tell password manager No. 4. Crash.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. 2. 3.
Actual Results: All tabs/windows crash.
Expected Results: Moz works fine with this site. Logs in perfectly.
None really.
WFM, Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030112 Phoenix/0.5
user245@hotmail.com, please reopen if you can reproduce with a current nightly build installed into a clean directory and a with a new profile.

bug.short_desc: Failed to load file:///opt/mozilla/phoenix/chrome/packages/core/contextHelp.js

long_desc.thetext:
When Page Info is launched, an error is printed to console:
Failed to load file:///opt/mozilla/phoenix/chrome/packages/core/contextHelp.js
This has happened since at least 0.5, and it's still happening in a build from two days ago. Surprised there wasn't a bug filed.

Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030103 Phoenix/0.5
Not getting this on Windows...

When posting a bug, please include the build ID (help -> about)
WFM Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030125 Phoenix/0.5
worksforme with a build from this morning on RH8.
Yes, seems to be fixed in recent builds.

bug.short_desc: Clicking on help related link brings up popup window but no data is displayed window is blank.
bug.bug_file_loc: http://pages.ebay.com/help/buy/search_tips.html (and any help related links on ebay)

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030105 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030105 Phoenix/0.5
Any "help" related link on eBay site brings up a popup window. This window is either blank (white) or displays for part of a second then clears. Some URLs are: http://pages.ebay.com/help/buy/search_tips.html http://pages.ebay.com/help/account/my_ebay_bidding.html http://pages.ebay.com/search/items/basicsearch.html I've tried others and they (help links) all seem to not display. Displays correctly in IExplorer 6.0.2800 and Netscape Communicator 4.8
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Click on eBay help related link 2. 3.
Actual Results: Popup window appears, labeled "eBay Help Hub - Phoenix" Sometimes it fills with color and text, for less than a second, then goes blank. Other times it pops up white and remains white.
Expected Results: Popup window should appear, fill with color and text. NOTE: IExplorer 6 fills with color, yellow, and text which remains. Netscape Communicator 4.8 fills with color, yellow, and text which blinks on then off then returns and remains after a short delay (1 - 2 seconds).
I noticed it originally with build .4 yesterday. Couldn't find any other help popup window sites to check them.
worksforme with Phoenix and Mozilla builds from today.

bug.short_desc: Table appears with the first and second column offset from the rest of the columns.

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
In the page: http://www.urldir.com/bt/chart.php?tool_a=b2%2FCafeLog&tool_b=MovableType&tool_c=Nucleus&tool_d=BlogWorks+XML&tool_e=GreyMatter&+GO%21=compare the table should view nice and clearly, but instead there is a strange offset in the table rendering.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to http://www.urldir.com/bt/chart.php?tool_a=b2%2FCafeLog&tool_b=MovableType&tool_c=Nucleus&tool_d=BlogWorks+XML&tool_e=GreyMatter&+GO%21=compare 2. Look at table. Actual Results: Table has columns that are shoved up.
Expected Results: A nice simple table.
worksforme in Phoenix and Mozilla builds from this morning.

bug.short_desc: crash when clicking on a link on main page which affects a child page

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
On the page: http://www.bu.edu/met/about/info_session.html, the links on the right hand side which specify a location (Charles River, Tyngsboro, etc) will lauch a child page. Now if the child page is open and then you click on the Parent page again and click on a link, Phoenix will crash.
Repeated several times.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open main page: http://www.bu.edu/met/about/info_session.html and click on a location link in the frame in the center of the page: Link: "Charles River"
2. After child page has loaded, go back to parent page and click on another link: "Tyngsboro".
3. Windows XP will launch its script to report a crash and Phoenix will close
Actual Results: Phoenix crashes
Expected Results: It should have updated the child page with new results.

Have you tried a newer build to see if the problem exists?
WFM Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021228 Phoenix/0.5
WFM with latest Phoenix build. Please reopen if you can still reproduce with a current build.

bug.short_desc: consistent page fault in MSVCRT.DLL on site

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Going to the site http://www.morrowindfiles.com/ causes Phoenix to produce a page fault and thus crash (exit to windows). This happened everytime I tried the site and I'm unable to provide any more information.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Goto http://www.morrowindfiles.com/
Actual Results: Page fault in MSVCRT.DLL
Expected Results: Uh, not crashed. :)

Reporter, could you try again with the latest nightly and a new profile? Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Printing does not occur until after Phoenix is closed

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Phoenix is not able to completely send the document to be printed to the printer-- usually "print progress" indicator (which pops up after I click Ok in the print dialog box)stops part way through and hangs. Happens mostly on longer documents.
Reproducible: Sometimes
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Equipment used is a HP Deskjet 842c printer; Go to any webpage, select print from file menu. Click "Ok" to print. 2. 3.
Actual Results: 'Preparing to Print' Progress bar froze at a certain percentage (31% often, 80 percent sometimes). No printing occurs, not even to the stated percentage. Windows printer dialog box under status says that it's spooling. If I click cancel and then try to print again, I get a "Printer not Available" error. When I quit the browser window the printer kicks in and I get the 31% or 80% of the documents pages printed out.
Expected Results: Should have printed normally.
Printing is normal in all other software including Mozilla 1.0
unable to reproduce with a current build.

bug.short_desc: Tooltips background garbled (probably bad buffer wipe)

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
When you look at the tooltips in phoenix 0.5, the background is garbled, like a memory buffer that wasn't cleaned out before being used. the bug is visible 95% of the time, going to 100% after some usage. I've tried this on 3 different computers (one Mandrake 8.1, one Mandrake 8.2 and one Debian, all reproduced the bug flawlessly, pun not intended).
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Open phoenix 0.5 2.look at the different tooltips in the toolbar, or on the page 3.repeat 2 or 3 times until you get a consistent stream of wrong (but pretty) backgrounds
Actual Results: the text for the tooltips is there, it's just that the background is not clean
Expected Results: a clean white (or colored, or textured) background.

Reporter, could you please try with the latest nightly and a new profile?
This is WFM using Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021225 Phoenix/0.5

Just tried the latest nightly (26/12) and the problems still there, sorry.
Hope this helps in any case
David
what theme are you using? can u reproduce this with the default theme?
No problems with default theme and a current build.

Please reopeon if you can reproduce with a current nightly build and you've tested to see that the problem doesn't also exist in the latest Mozilla nightly build. Be sure to install into a clean directory and test with a new profile and no 3rd pary extensions installed. Worksforme with latest builds.

bug.short_desc: Browser crashes as soon as page is loaded.

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Page loads OK using Mozilla 1.0.1 (Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.0.1) Gecko/20021003, build 2002100313)
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. I type in the URL above 2. Hit Return 3. Browser crashes

WFM using NT 4.0 and Gecko/20021216 Phoenix/0.5
As the version you're using is rather old: did you check a new version of Phoenix? If not, then please obtain a nightly build from
http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/phoenix/nightly/latest-trunk/
and install it into a new directory together with a _new_ profile and try again.
WFM using Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021222 Phoenix/0.5
wtf? sorry, I must have clicked in the wrong place.
wfm Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021222 Phoenix/0.5. however two of the java applets on the page would not load so the crash maybe related to the java.
WFM in 20030116 on WinXP. I don't install Java, either.
asjl: what version of jre do you have and are you sure its installed correctly ? codeword "symlink"

Here's a list (from XP's Event log) about the crashes I'm having. I believe the crashes happen just as page is supposed to be rendered (Title bar/url are correct, but the browser's window has yet to render content)...
Faulting application phoenix.exe, version 1.3.0.0, faulting module nspr4.dll, version 4.2.1.0, fault address 0x00012259.
Faulting application phoenix.exe, version 1.3.0.0, faulting module nspr4.dll, version 4.2.1.0, fault address 0x00012259.
Faulting application phoenix.exe, version 1.3.0.0, faulting module ntdll.dll, version 5.1.2600.1106, fault address 0x0002564b.
I could send my system information, but I don't think it's configuration dependent (these same types of crashes happen on my home PC as well). I am using "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5Oh", it's the first and only version of Phoenix I've played with.

bug.short_desc: Cannot input Japanese characters

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
You cannot input japanese text anymore.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. With IME, switch to Japanese 2. Select a field in a form or in the search bar 3. Type some text using katakana or hiragana
Actual Results: Every characters are showned as question marks ???????????
Expected Results: Show Japanese characters
Worked fine in Phoenix 0.4
Major bug because Phoenix become unusable in Japanese and possibly other languages.
Complains about this bug at http://www.mozillazine.org/forums/viewtopic.php?t=2204&highlight=
Input of Japanese characters is broken with Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Added dependency with bug 180674
Walter: try with a recent build of Mozilla from the trunk before declaring phoenix-only.
Bug also does not exist in Mozilla-latest (Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021209), under Windows 2000. I believe it is Phoenix-specific, aswell.

Pasting Japanese text appears to work just fine (e.g., entering some text into Notepad, then copying and pasting into Phoenix). This makes me think it is just a problem with recieving text from the IME, not some kind of problem with displaying it.
*** Bug 184785 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

When the Windows locale (that should have no consequences on unicode softwares) set to japanese, it works fine.
I guess there is some non-unicode hidden in Phoenix codebase. With Mozilla 1.2.1 Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.2.1) Gecko/20021130 the bug is not present, that must be a Phoenix-specific bug.
Other complains about this bug but with Chinese characters : http://www.mozillazine.org/forums/viewtopic.php?p=22573
The bug disappeared somewhere between nighly 20021219 and 20030101, as reported on http://www.mozillazine.org/forums/viewtopic.php?t=3742
wfm

bug.short_desc: trying to install an extension (Linky, Mouse Gestures, Radial Gestures, etc.) leads to a permanently locked profile

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Konqueror/3; Linux) Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Whenever I try to install an extension, the install process works fine. But when I exit the browser and try to get back in, it insists that the profile I installed from is in use. Once this happens, the profile is unusable, even after logout / reboot / manually deleting the "lock" file in .phoenix directory. This has been a problem in both 0.4 and 0.5.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Open tools -> prefs -> themes and extensions 2.Goto "Get New Extensions" 3.Install an extension 4.Exit browser 5.Launch browser again Actual Results: Insists that profile is in use.
Expected Results: Open broswer with correct profile.
This happens with the plain vanilla download of Phoenix.
unable to reproduce with a Linux build from this morning

bug.short_desc: Advanced JavaScript Options shows wrong status

assigned_to.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030201 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030201 Phoenix/0.5
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030201 Phoenix/0.5 [Tools]-[Options]-[Web Features]-[x]Enable Javascript-[Advanced] “Advanced JavaScript Options Dialog’s Checkbox” shows opposite meaning to actual action.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Start Phoenix with a new profile. 1.Open [Tools]-[Options]-[Web Features] 2.Click Enable Javascript-[Advanced] Actual Results: Allow scripts to: [ ]Move or resize existing windows [ ]Raise or lower windows [ ]Hide the status bar [ ]Change status bar text [ ]Change images
Expected Results: Should indicate actual preference, like the old version of phoenix do: Allow scripts to: [X]Move or resize existing windows [X]Raise or lower windows [X]Hide the status bar [X]Change status bar text [X]Change images
ben: Please fix this bug.
Reassigning to Ben and confirming.

who.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext: Fixed.
Thank you Bob. Now it works for me with Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030202 Phoenix/0.5 and VERIFIED.

bug.short_desc: Phoenix always crashes when I try and open this site.

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Phoenix always crashes when I try and open http://setiathome.ssl.berkeley.edu/stats/team/team_129100.htm
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to http://setiathome.ssl.berkeley.edu/stats/team/team_129100.htm with Phoenix 2. 3. Actual Results: Phoenix crashes
Expected Results: The page should have been displayed.
WFM using Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030202 Phoenix/0.5. But the page says "Web page missing".

WFM Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030202 Phoenix/0.5
I get a missing page at the original URL as well; I added an 'l' to the 'htm' to get 'html' and the page renders without issue.
http://setiathome.ssl.berkeley.edu/stats/team/team_129100.html
reporter: [Bill Gates !?], do you get the same problem with Mozilla? have you tried using a new profile?

Nothing special about that page. Lots of plain html, though it doesn't even make 4.01 transitional.
WFM Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030125 Phoenix/0.5

It works fine on Mozilla 1.3a. It's just Phoenix that always crashes. I'm not sure what you mean by trying a new profile. Are you guys saying it works fine under phoenix for you? And are you running Windows XP? Or something else? Oh, and sorry about messing up the URL.

Don't try with Mozilla 1.3a, try with Mozilla's latest nightly. And by the way, you should have tested the URI with Phoenix latest nightly too. Phoenix 0.5 is now almost two month old (and for Phoenix, it's very old). To learn how to create a new profile, please read http://texturizer.net/phoenix/bugs.html
WFM means "Works for me". Alan and I are running Windows 2000, David is running GNU/Linux. So yes, it works without problem for us. And the new URI also WFM.

Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030202 Phoenix/0.5
Works fine on Win 2K

WFM, too, using Windows NT 4.0 SP6 and Gecko/20030203 Phoenix/0.5
I think we should wait until Bill tried with the latest nightly and a fresh profile - or perhaps someone else can check this using XP...
Works for me on XP

Ok - well, due to comment #8 and all the other comments I think it's ok to mark this one as WFM.
Bill: If problem still persists with latest nightly build and fresh profile as suggested by Sébastien in comment #5 please feel free to re-open this bug!

bug.short_desc: when i type about:plugins in the location bar, it displayes an error message

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
when i type about:plugins in the location bar, it displayes an error message. The error message is "The Procedure entry point NS_NewUnionEnumerator could not be located in the dynamic link library xpcom.dll". When i click OK, it shows all the plugins properly. However this error message appears before the proper outcome...
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. In the Phoenix browser location bar type about:plugins 2. 3. Actual Results: Now the error message will appear, asking you to click on "ok".
Expected Results: It should have displayed all the plugins found the browser

WFM with latest nightly. Reporter, could you please test this with the latest nightly and a fresh profile (more info about that here: http://texturizer.net/phoenix/bugs.html ), with no extension and added theme?

Yes, the error message is not there now in the latest nightly. Thanks for pointing out this. In future i'll always confirm with the latest builds.. Thanks..
This problem is not present in this version. Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030207 Phoenix/0.5
Cheers.,
Incorrect resolution. This bug is not 'fixed', it's 'invalid' or it 'works for me', since the bug doesn't exist.
wfm

bug.short_desc: Paste does not work in HTTP-proxy field

long_desc.thetext:
Version: 0.2 (Build 20021001)
I went to IE, opened by network config, select the name of the proxy server, right click - Copy. Then I went to Phoenix, opened my preferences-....- right click inside the text field for "HTTP-Proxy", selected "Paste". I can see my CPU go to 100% for maybe half of a second, but the value is not pasted.
can you paste from ie into other fields in Mozilla (like the urlbar or the comments textarea in this bug)?

Additional info: only the "mouse paste" does not work. The keyboard shortcut (Ctrl-V) works.
I can paste in almost all the fields (URL, other fields in other preferences), but I can not mouse-paste in any of the "Connection Tab" field.
confirmed. that field does not accept a context menu paste. This is windows and linux
*** Bug 177460 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I can middle-button paste in Linux, but not context menu paste.
Release 0.4
*** Bug 179513 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 104661 ***
Verified
