bug.short_desc: Phoenix crashes trying to display the demo page.

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021204 Phoenix/0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021204 Phoenix/0.4
The demo page is a cut down version of a page that originally gave this crash. What's left that could be related to the problem is the following:
* A CSS setting of "p { max-width: 45em; }"
* Use of the UTF-8 encoding.
Actually the number of characters in the single text paragraph seems to be critical as well. If I take out the _first two characters_, the crash does not occur. Also removing other characters, or the "em" tags, or the asterisks, can help.
If I remove the "meta" element for UTF-8, Phoenix does not crash, but the page initally takes surprisingly long to render.
This bug seems to depend on a lot of small details, and it probably appears only once in a very blue moon.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce:
Mozilla does not crash on this page.
Possibly this is related to bug 175558, who knows...
Since this seems to be related to the text width ("max-with: 45em") it wouldn't surprise me if this bug only occurs with certain font size settings, certain font families, etc.
WFM Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021129 Phoenix/0.4

WFM Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021204 Phoenix/0.4
Bertilo, did you do a clean install of Phoenix, as suggested in the release notes? Do you use any extensions?

No, I did not do a fresh install, and I do use a couple of extensions.
So, I just did a complete reinstall (same Phoenix version), without any extensions, and virgin profile. At first the test page gave no trouble. Then I set the font to "monotype-arial" (the sans-serif setting), like I usually do, and the font size to 16px (those were the only settings I touched). And Phoenix immediately crashed at the test page. I tested with "monotype-times new roman" too - no problem.
The font "monotype-arial" normally gives no problems. I have about 700 pages similar to the original problem page (the same general content, the same CSS...), and Phoenix have no problems with them. It's just this one page, from which I've isolated the troublesome paragraph and CSS in the test page.

Works fine on Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021206 Phoenix/0.4.
I had some problems with CSS too... bug 182926

Just tried to dupe the problem using Gecko/20021214 Phoenix/0.5 but had no luck.
Reporter: Can you please describe step by step what you did to make Phoenix crash? The problem is, that I don't have any "monotype-arial" entry contained in any of the four comboboxes in screen Tools -> Preferences -> Fonts and colors. So I played around with several other fonts and font soizes but Phoenix didn't crashed on your demo page...

The steps are:
(0. Use Linux.) 1. Use a virgin install of Phoenix. 2. Set font to "monotype-arial". 3. Set font size to 16px. 4. Load test page. 5. Watch Phoenix crash.
As I've already written, this bug seems to show itself only under very peculiar and specific circumstances. E.g. deleting one or two characters in the test page will result in Phoenix having no problems. Perhaps you'll need to use my exact window size and resolution...
Perhaps the crashes I've seen on the following page are related, although there is no need for "monotype-arial":
<URL:http://www.akademio-de-esperanto.org/fundamento/ekzercaro.php>
For that page you need to pump up the font size a bit with text-zoom, and Phoenix will crash (Mozilla survives).

Sorry - even with the second page you reported I'm not able to crash Phoenix on my system - I loaded the page completely and then increased the font size even to the maximum possible value, but the only thing I noticed was, that Phoenix needs a while to complete this task when reaching larger font sizes...

It could be the second page bug needs a TrueType font to eat. I think I used "Times New Roman" (monotype) when I got the second crash. The original bug only eats "monotype-arial" though. I've used "monotype-arial" for all browsing for a long time, and only the one test page (and the original version of it) has ever given me any grief.
Bugs are a weird species...
Bertilo, can you reproduce this in Mozilla (getting a talkback report from a Mozilla crash would help a lot) or reproduce in a debug build so we can get a stack trace?

Sorry, Ada, but this bug has never ever showed itself in Mozilla, only in Phoenix. I still get it from time to time. Then I just restart Phoenix, and switch to a different font before loading the page again.
Are there debug builds of Phoenix?

Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030202 Phoenix/0.5
This page gives no problem
I can't reproduce this on Windows on the second test page using today's build. When trying to get to the first test page I only get a 404.

Sorry guys, the testpage at http://www.bertilow.com/div/crash-phoenix/ died when I reinstalled my system and did a clean up of my web pages. No back-up! :( I don't think it matters though, since no one has been able to reproduce the error. I'm using Mozilla right now (not Phoenix) and I don't get these crashes anymore.
You can kill this bug if you want to. If the beast turns up again, I'll report a new bug.
Well - so I mark this one as "Works for me"... If anyone has any objections on this feel free to change the state of the bug - I don't want to mark it as "Invalid" as obviously a problem existed.
Verified.

bug.short_desc: Cannot disable JavaScript with new UI

assigned_to.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030208 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030208 Phoenix/0.5
Cannot disable JavaScript using the new preference dialogbox. This phenomenon was noted after checkin of Bug 191524 (Mega Preferences Reorg.).
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Start Phoenix with a new profile. 2.Open [Tools]-[Options...]-[Web Features]. 3.Un-check "Enable JavaScript" checkbox. 4.Click [OK] to close options dialogbox. 5.Reopen [Tools]-[Options...]-[Web Features]. Actual Results: "Enable JavaScript" checkbox is checked and JavaScript is still enabled.
Expected Results: "Enable JavaScript" checkbox must be un-checked and JavaScript should be disabled.
This bug has been reported: http://www.mozillazine.org/forums/viewtopic.php?t=5441 http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=191650#c6
Confirming and reassigning to Ben.

Actually, you don't even need to close the Options window and to open it again. Just uncheck "Enable javascript", then switch to another Options panel and switch back to the Web Features panel, and the pref is checked again.

Created attachment 115708 fix
fix Mega Preferences Reorg. regression

Created attachment 115710 fix v.2
This version of the patch also fixes the initial button enable/disable.

Comment on attachment 115710 fix v.2
It was the other way around :) Thank you for pointing at the problem!
fixed.

Created attachment 115757 Patch a deficiency
This patch fixes following deficiency. 1. Open [Tools]-[Options…]-[Web Features] 2. Un-check [Enable JavaScript] *note Advanced button is disabled. 3. Switch to another Options panel and switch back to the Web Features panel. Actual Results: Advanced button is enabled
Expected Results: Advanced button should be disabled
*** Bug 195228 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I grabbed today's nightly and it works fine with new profiles and 0.5 profiles. I experienced a problem with a post pref reorg profile, though. Try with a new profile.
Ooops, sorry, norority, I didn't understand the bug correctly, now the 'advanced' button is really fixed. Thanks!

Comment on attachment 115757 Patch a deficiency
I refactored some code, though. but this patch and the previous one were essentially correct.

Pierre: Thanks for the review and polishing.

bug.short_desc: gtk_init undefined when building Phoenix with gtk2

long_desc.thetext:
In toolkit/xre/nsAppRunner.cpp, the test for including gtk/gtk.h is #ifdef MOZ_WIDGET_GTK (line 332) while the test for calling gtk_main is #if defined(MOZ_WIDGET_GTK) || defined(MOZ_WIDGET_GTK2) (line 1807)
So, when --enable-default-toolkit=gtk2, we get an undefined reference to gtk_main when compiling nsAppRunner.cpp.
Changing line 332 to match line 1807 fixes the problem, and allows the compilation to finish.
I'm building on a Debian/unstable powerpc box.

/home/tt/src/mozilla/mozilla/toolkit/xre/nsAppRunner.cpp:1812: `gtk_init' undeclared (first use this function)
debian testing/unstable pc, hw->all. summary~=s/gtk_main/gtk_init/ -- no mention of gtk_main in that file.
looks like http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsview2.cgi?diff_mode=context&whitespace_mode=show&file=nsAppRunner.cpp&root=/cvsroot&subdir=mozilla/toolkit/xre&command=DIFF_FRAMESET&rev1=1.6&rev2=1.7 (bryner%netscape.com Mar 3 01:49) is what changed gtk_init to be called with MOZ_WIDGET_GTK2 as well as MOZ_WIDGET_GTK.
i checked in a fix.
I built Phoenix successfully: VERIFIED FIXED.

Will, I'd suggest you change severity to "major", because the loss of this functionality means a major reduction of usability on these platforms.

Another suggestion: please change the word "icon" in the summary to "cursor" and remove "windows 95" (or add "windows nt") to better reflect what seems to be actually happening here ;). Sorry for the spam.
I have the same problem on W95c with all Phoenix nightlies since Nov 27.

Is this same problem happening in recent mozilla nightlies? Or is it phoenix specific?
If it is, bug 56167 might be resurfacing....
only phoenix

Tested with a corresponding Mozilla nightly (2002112908-trunk); everything's normal there, so this is definitely Phoenix-specific and seems to only affect win os versions without a system hand cursor.
WFM under W2K with a build from 2002/11/28.
Tried it again with a newer build and a clean install. Still WFM under W2K with a build from 2002/12/01
WFM with Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021201 Phoenix/0.4

So this seems to be a confirmation that this only doesn't work on Win 95 and NT4 without IE4 Active Desktop add-on. Also see the corresponding thread on MozillaZine: http://www.mozillazine.org/forums/viewtopic.php?t=1572
Seeing this bug with 11-28-2002 NT4 SP6a too; Since it has been confirmed by enough "smart" users, I'm marking it as NEW.
I'm seeing this problem on Windows NT4. Another "smart" user. :)
Updating summary.
Another confirmation from an NT4 user - build information from about is: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; WinNT4.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5.
Created attachment 108734 Additional related behavior
Did someone checked this on Windows 98? Or is it really just related to Windows versions without Active Desktop as mentioned in comment #3 or comment #12 ?
WFM on Windows 98 SE

I have NT4 WITH Active Desktop installed and I experience this bug with Phoenix 0.5. I've noticed that it stalls on whatever the cursor happens to be. If I rollover a link coming from text, the cursor remains the 'I', if I rollover from an image, the cursor is an arrow, if I speedily rollover a link from the window frame, I'll get a resize-handle. I don't think this bug has anything to do with Active Desktop.
travis: does your system have a system hand cursor?
Yes, my system has the hand cursor. Unless 0.5 uses a different hand cursor? The cursor worked as it is supposed to with 0.4.

Hello,
can I help with more information?
I'm wondering why this bug cannot be fixed. Still sitting here with a Phoenix nightly from November 2002.
Well, the target milestone for this bug is set to Phoenix 0.6 - so it seems like we'll have to be patient... :o)
I can confirm this bug under Windows NT4. This problem has, however, only occured since I installed phoenix 0.5, 0.4 worked fine.

It looks to me like we aren't including the IDC_SELECTANCHOR resource. Win98, 2K, etc. word because they have a system IDC_HAND resource available. Win 95 and NT do not.
See http://lxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/source/widget/src/windows/nsWindow.cpp#2472
IDC_SELECTANCHOR is defined in widget/src/build/widget.rc as the widget/src/build/res/select.cur file.
I just hunted through the EXE and all the DLLs in the phoenix directory and there are no cursors. Obviously we don't use any of the others defined in widget.rc, but we need IDC_SELECTANCHOR.
cc: bryner who's done some Phoenix build work before. Brian, any idea why this cursor isn't getting included in the .exe?

IIRC, this bug appeared just after Brian made a major build mod (making Phoenix a static build ?).
Dean's analysis seems to confirm this.
I was just looking into that. A lot of people have had problems getting resources into EXEs, but I haven't found a generic solution (non-C++Builder) yet.
cls, do you know what we need to do to get the cursor resource linked into phoenix.exe?
For a static build, you'd have to set RESFILE in the phoenix Makefile to point to widget/src/build/widget.res.
So, the problem is that for a static phoenix build, we're already setting RESFILE to splash.res. Is there an easy way to do multiple resource files?

We're not setting RESFILE to splash.res, we're setting RCINCLUDE to splash.rc. As far as I can tell this does nothing, since there's no splash bitmap in the .exe.
This works, btw. I added "RESFILE = $(topsrcdir)/widget/src/build/widget.res" right underneath the RCINCLUDE line in browser/app/Makefile.in, and I've now got cursors in my phoenix.exe.
OK, obviously I was wrong. splash.rc defines the application icon, which is kinda important.
Dean, you're a genius.

Created attachment 116176 hack
You can only specify one RESFILE. If you specify multiples, you get a LNK4059 error (eg. "widget.res : warning LNK4059: splash.res already specified; additional resource file ignored"). I also was unable to get an RCINCLUDE and a RESFILE to live in harmony, due to the same error.
This patch just hardcodes the cursor resource that we need into the .exe. It's the only way I could get all the resources we need into the static .exe.
Well, thanks to Dean's great work here it looks like we have a solution. When can this be checked in?

Comment on attachment 116176 hack
If I wrap this in an #IFDEF BUILD_STATIC_LIBS, will the compiler see it or does only the build process see that?

Right now there's no #define for that, but you could add one to the Makefile.in, i.e.:
ifdef BUILD_STATIC_LIBS RCFLAGS += -DMOZ_STATIC_BUILD endif
Thanks Brian. I'll do that and check it in.
Excellent, that did the trick. Checked in.
Thanks a lot Dean for your detective work to fix this. I'm looking forward to downloading the first Phoenix (or whatever) nightly since over two months.
This fix should be in 20020308, shouldn't it? Sadly it still doesn't work for me.
Hrm. The cursor's definitely in the .exe so it must be something else as well. Sorry 'bout that, it's tough to test since I don't have Windows 95 or NT 4.
OK, nsToolkit::mDLLInstance is going to return 0 because it's set in DLLMain, which is never called for a static build.

Or I could read the entire source code before spamming everyone. We set it in the creator for static builds.
http://lxr.mozilla.org/seamonkey/source/widget/src/windows/nsToolkit.cpp#551
I'll have to do more digging, which means (sigh) that I'll need to build a static build again.
mine
This is fixed now.
Yep, I can confirm this is fixed now with 20020310 on NT4. Thanks again.
Verifying based on lazlo's comment 50.

bug.short_desc: Netscape-and-compatible Flash 6 installer won't recognize Phoenix

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
When I ran the Netscape-and-compatible Flash 6 installer, and it asked me to choose which browser on which I wanted Flash installed, the list was blank. Even if you click "Browse", and and go where "phoenix.exe" is located, it still won't see it. (Even if I click "Next" without choosing a browser, it will look like it is installing Flash somewhere, but it's not.) Flash and Shockwave will not recognize Phoenix 0.5.
However, there is a work-around. I copied the items in Mozilla's "Plugins" folder to Phoenix's.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run the Flash 6 installer. 2. Follow the prompts. 3. When you get to the promp asking on which browser is Flash to be installed, the list is blank.
Actual Results: Flash (and Shockwave) weren't installed.
Expected Results: Flash should've recognize Phoenix, and installed properly.

Phoenix does not add the information that the Flash and Shockwave installers require to the system registry. This is normally handled by the installation programs for Mozilla based products, but Phoenix doesn't have an official installer.
Workaround 1: Use the unofficial Phoenix installer, available at http://blackdiamond.mozdev.org/installer/
Workaround 2: Add this information to the system registry by hand. See http://plugindoc.mozdev.org/phoenix.html for instructions.
Resolving as duplicate of bug 182409 (Phoenix needs an installer), as this would solve the problem for the vast majority of users. It's not a direct duplicate, but would be solved by fixing 182409 because of functionality provided by the installer.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 182409 ***
verified dupe.
v

In the same way that long titles being handled badly by Enlightenment under linux forms a vulnerability (titles longer than say 256 cahrs, which you can do on a web page, and the browser then puts it in the tilebar, cause major havoc as E tries to shorten the title by showing the ends of it with "..." in the middle), so this forms a "vulnerability" -- i can now have my access to a website basically "denied" by someone dropping in a giant favicon.ico file.
Would appreciate updates on this.

bug.short_desc: Satchel autocomplete only works on first tab

assigned_to.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext:
Found in Phoenix 0.4 on win2k w SP2 installed.
Satchel's autocomplete is only offering me autocomplete options on form fields displayed on the first tab opened in a new browser window.
I never see any satchel options on tabs opened subsequently in a browser window, whether that tab was opened using "New Tab" or by Ctrl+Click on a link.
This behaviour persists even if I close the original tab to put another tab at the front of the tab set: I still see no satchel autocomplete options.
The Ctrl+PgUp/PgDn shortcut which brings up the satchel list when focus is on a form field in the first tab acts only to switch tabs when focus is on a form field in other tabs.
Text entered in the same field in other tabs is added to the satchel set which appears on the same form field in the first opened tab.
*** Bug 179710 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I can confirm this with 2002-11-12 on Linux.

Created attachment 108477 Fix for autocomplete not working in tabs
I don't have a complete understanding why this bug exists, but this patch takes care of the problem.

Created attachment 108579 Better fix, as well as indenting changes for detachFormFill
This is a better/faster version of the previous fix, along with some whitespace changes to detachFormFill().

who.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext: What's happening is that in tabbrowser.xml, the autocompletepopup attribute of the child browser that is created by hand is not set when all the init attributes are set. A simpler fix is to patch it there (1 line). I have done this and checked it in.

who.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext: Fix checked in.

who.name: Ben Goodger (use ben at mozilla dot org for email)

long_desc.thetext: what is needed for this to be working in Mozilla?
Satchel is Phoenix only. Mozilla AFAIK has the old form manager that is replaced by Satchel in Phoenix.

bug.short_desc: gtk2 build fails when linking phoenix-bin (NS_CreateNativeAppSupport undefined)

long_desc.thetext:
From a CVS build pulled at 4pm PST, I can't link phoenix-bin:
c++ -o phoenix-bin -I/usr/X11R6/include -fno-rtti -fno-exceptions -Wall -Wconversion -Wpointer-arith -Wcast-align -Woverloaded-virtual -Wsynth -Wno-ctor-dtor-privacy -pedantic -Wno-long-long -fshort-wchar -pthread -pipe -DNDEBUG -DTRIMMED -O2 nsBrowserApp.o -L../../dist/bin -L../../dist/lib -ldl -lm ../../dist/lib/libxulapp_s.a -L../../dist/bin -lmozjs -L../../dist/bin -lxpcom -L/home/alex/src/mozilla/dist/lib -lplds4 -lplc4 -lnspr4 -lpthread -ldl -Wl,--export-dynamic -lgtk-x11-2.0 -lgdk-x11-2.0 -latk-1.0 -lgdk_pixbuf-2.0 -lm -lpangoxft-1.0 -lpangox-1.0 -lpango-1.0 -lgobject-2.0 -lgmodule-2.0 -ldl -lglib-2.0 ../../dist/lib/libxulapp_s.a(nsAppRunner.o)(.text+0x38dc): In function `xre_main(int, char**, nsXREAppData const&)': : undefined reference to `NS_CreateNativeAppSupport(nsINativeAppSupport**)' ../../dist/lib/libxulapp_s.a(nsAppRunner.o)(.text+0x3b00): In function `xre_main(int, char**, nsXREAppData const&)': : undefined reference to `NS_CreateSplashScreen(nsISplashScreen**)' ../../dist/lib/libxulapp_s.a(nsAppRunner.o)(.text+0x3b08): In function `xre_main(int, char**, nsXREAppData const&)': : undefined reference to `NS_CanRun()' collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
I can work around this failure by using either the GTK1 or generic implementation of these functions.
Generic: Take out MOZ_WIDGET_GTK2 from lines 354 and 389.
GTK1: Modify toolkit/xre/Makefile.in to include nsNativeAppSupportGtk.cpp in SHAREDSRCS and include MOZ_WIDGET_GTK2 in the test to define splash_xpm on line 54 of nsBrowserApp.cpp.
The generic option seems to be what happened before version 1.11 of nsAppRunner.cpp.

Are you still seeing this? This should have been fixed as of 2003-03-12 by a checkin by bryner. If you still get an error please reopen.
-->Fixed

No, I'm not still seeing this -- that checkin fixed this.
VERIFIED FIXED.

bug.short_desc: Implement about:phoenix (or about:new-name)

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.4a) Gecko/20030314 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.4a) Gecko/20030314 Phoenix/0.5
In the URL bar, typing about:phoenix results in *no* action being performed. However, about:mozilla does give the usual reference from "The Book of Mozilla".
A search of Bugzilla for "about" under product "Phoenix" currently shows seven bugs, none similar to this one.
I would expect about:phoenix to be more relevant for this product (or, more appropriately, about:newname when the new name for Phoenix is chosen). So:
1. Implement about:newname 2. Remove about:mozilla
Of course, if you want to demonstrate the product's heritage, we can keep about:mozilla.
Note: I have observed this behaviour under a number of platforms and OSs for nightlies up to and including 20030314.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce:

Removing about:mozilla is bug 172854 (WONTFIX). If you want to have informations specific to Phoenix, just type about:

bug.short_desc: When a bookmark has the same string as Name and Keyword, Keyword won't work

long_desc.thetext:
Using build 20021008 on w2k.
When a bookmark has the same string as Name and Keyword, the keyword won't work, and it'll redirect to a Google search.
For example: I bookmark some-example-page.com, and then click on Manage bookmark to change its name and to add a keyword to it. I put "example" as Name, and "example" as keyword. Then I type "example" in the urlbar, and it redirects me to "keyword:example". If I change either the name or the keyword (say I use "ex" instead of "example" as keyword), then the keyword'll work.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 144875 ***
v.

bug.short_desc: Phoenix erroneously thinks its not the default browser

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
Everytime I start up Phoenix .5 it asks me if I want to make it the default browser, even though its already been registered as the default HTML handler. This can be verified through the registry.
Mozilla 1.0 used to do this, but it was fixed in 1.1. Perhaps Phoenix is looking at more than the default html handler when checking to see if its default. Is it checking all file extensions it can render?
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Start 2. ???? 3. Profit!
Actual Results: I get the dialogue box asking me to make Phoenix the default browser. I only use IE on occasion and its configured to not make itself or ask to be made default.
Expected Results: Not constantly ask to be made default after its been made so.
Registry key to check default:
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\http\shell\open\command
WFM on WinXP. Reporter, do you still see this bug? Can you test with a new Windows account?

WFM.
Reporter, please reopen if you're still experiencing this with the latest nightly and a fresh profile.

Thank you for your time... Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Refreshed the page 2. Checked it again over 7 hours later Actual Results: Nothing changed, still look bad :( Expected Results: I don't know, if she DID code something wrong then improve the warnings that there are misscodings so a person can find that out.

Sounds like a standard Java programming thing, if I can't minimise the program then KILL IT... how about catching the error somehow?

bug.short_desc: Drag & drop duplicate URL to desktop "Confirm File Replace" dialog not selected

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20021207 Phoenix/0.5
When dragging/dropping a URL from the URL entry bar to the desktop, if a shortcut with the name already exists, a "Confirm File Replace" dialog box appears, but it is not the active window. It is not possible to click any of the buttons on the dialog, or move the dialog. I must use ALT-TAB to cycle through windows to the "Confirm File Replace" dialog. Moving the dialog causes "window trails" on the underlying Phoenix window.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Drag & Drop any URL to desktop 2. Do it again 3. Try to click a button on the "Confirm File Replace" dialog box 4. Use ALT-TAB to select the dialog box 5. Drag the dialog around.
Actual Results: Can't click a button. Moving dialog box causes naughty dialog hoofey prints all over my nice clean Phoenix window. Waaaa!
Expected Results: Had dialog box selected

WFM with Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.4a) Gecko/20030313 Phoenix/0.5 The file is automatically replaced, there is no confirmation window. This is (was) probably a Mozilla issue anyway.
Reporter, feel free to reopen if you're still experiencing this with the latest nightly and a fresh profile.

bug.short_desc: Autofill in address bar needed

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030304 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.4a) Gecko/20030316 Phoenix/0.5
Phoenix should autofill the most likely result while typing. I realize Phoenix does not use the same autocomplete widget as Mozilla, but I think this would be a useful addition, especially once the learning machine from Mozilla is implemented.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to www.ibm.com 2. Start typing www.ibm in the address bar Actual Results: Drop down autocomplete appears
Expected Results: Phoenix should autofill www.ibm.com in addition to the drop down autocomplete appearing.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 186136 ***

Sebastien,
This is not a dupe of 186136, as that bug involves having a preference for this autocomplete functionality and has nothing to do with the functionality. I had already viewed that bug before filing this RFE, and it says nothing about not including this functionality in Phoenix, just that there will not be a pref in the options panel. This RFE involves creating the functionality in the autocomplete widget, not with creating an option in the Options panel. This could be togglable via prefs.js/user.js or set as a default. Because this is not a dupe I'm reopening it.
Bug 186136 isn't only about the option, but about the functionality (read the summary). That's why it's WONTFIX and not INVALID (just like bug 177612 or bug 179938).

Re-duplicating this bug. Bug 186136 is clearly not only about the pref for an autofill in the adress bar, but also about the functionality itself (that is why it has been marked WONTFIX).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 186136 ***
v.

bug.short_desc: Background redraw flashes black/white on any redraw of phoenix background

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030210 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030311 Phoenix/0.5
When any part of the phoenix browser is redrawn by the windows the background flashes black-white-black-white in quick succession. This is very irritating to the point where it can't be used without getting bloodshot eyes!
No web pages are being displayed, starts with blank page. Although it's all of the browser which does this - sidebar, address, etc. not just the page view.
I've given the Mozilla browser a test also on the same box with no sight of this feature.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Start the latest browser
Actual Results: Browser starts, background flickers, then settles. When any part of the window is redrawn the effect happens again - flickering twice.
Expected Results: A plain background should be drawn once.
Could a fix this improve the speed of the browser? I mean, is this a sign that the background is redrawn twice for every redraw event it gets? (Maybe just on XP)
Reproducable using any theme in standard install.
Machine:
Windows XP Professional 2002 SP.1 Celeron 1.7GHz 256MB
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 196308 ***
v.

bug.short_desc: Using "Open in Tabs" from an about:blank page causes first bookmark to open in wrong tab

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030221 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.3b) Gecko/20030221 Phoenix/0.5
If I have a single about:blank tab open and use the bookmark "Open in Tabs" feature, then the blank tab is sensibly used to open the first bookmark in the list.
However if I have multiple tabs open, including an about:blank page which is NOT the first tab, and the focus is currently on the blank tab, then when I click on "Open in Tabs" the first URL in the bookmark list is opened over the contents of the first tab, and the blank tab is left alone.
The subsequent URLs in the list are opened at the far right as expected.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a new blank tab to the right of the existing tabs, and move to this tab 2. Click the "Open in Tabs" option of any bookmark list
Actual Results: The first URL loads in the first tab; the blank tab is left alone, and the other URLs open at the right of the tab list.
Expected Results: If the blank tab was the right-most tab, I would expect the first URL to open in the blank tab, and the subsequent URLs to open to the right.
If the blank tab was not the right-most tab, then I would expect all the URLs to open in new tabs at the right. (The blank tab _could_ still be used in this circumstance, but this would separate the first URL from the rest which seems like a bad thing.)
One alternative would be to 'insert' the new tabs into the tab list, starting at the position of the blank tab -- this would maintain the URL sequence, and always utilise the blank tab.
I disabled Tab Browsing Extensions and re-tested this before submitting the bug (the behaviour remained the same, either way).
I haven't checked the latest build yet (sorry!), but I have observed this bug in various builds for the past few months and could find no mention of it in bugzilla, so it seemed likely that it continues to exist in the current builds.

Ah, my apologies folks... it looks like a TBE problem after all... I couldn't even find the relevant options outside of TBE when I downloaded the latest build, so I went back to the build I had been using and found that the "Disable Extension" button doesn't seem to take effect unless you shut down and restart the browser, so my earlier testing 'without TBE' was invalid.
Starting Phoenix with TBE disabled, I couldn't reproduce the problem.
Starting Phoenix with TBE enabled, the problem comes back.
This bug is therefore INVALID. You might want to take this up with the author of TBE (for his benefit check if it occurs in Mozilla as well).
v.

bug.short_desc: Midas demo doesn't work on Phoenix

long_desc.thetext:
build ID: 2003020508 on Win2k.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Load URL http://www.mozilla.org/editor/midasdemo/ 2. Enter text, 3. Text doesn't show up, clicking on buttons doesn't work either.
Works fine with Mozilla 2003020508 on Win2k.
Phoenix JavaScript console shows:
Error: uncaught exception: [Exception... "Component returned failure code: 0x80004005 (NS_ERROR_FAILURE) [nsIDOMNSHTMLDocument.designMode]" nsresult: "0x80004005 (NS_ERROR_FAILURE)" location: "JS frame :: http://www.mozilla.org/editor/midasdemo/ :: Start :: line 214" data: no]
This could be a dupe of 191637, since that bug also generates a lot of JS errors.
it seems designMode (Midas) is not implemented or "reachable" in Phoenix. Does this need to be exported ? Maybe the interface for Midas is not frozen yet, ccing brade.

Midas relies on the composer library (mozilla/editor/composer). If Phoenix wants to support Midas, then I'd check to ensure that the composer library is part of the build. If the library is part of the install and it still is failing, please let me know that.
For reference, midas landed on the trunk just after the 1.2 branch was made.

I opened another bug for this:
http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=186663
and it was marked enhancement.

Okay, dupe.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 186663 ***
verify dupe

bug.short_desc: Cursor disappears once the edit box loses and regains focus

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030108 Phoenix/0.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030108 Phoenix/0.5
As one types text into an input box (of, say, Phoenix forum), switches focus to one of the menu items and gets back to writing on the same input box, the cursor does not show up anymore. You can continue on typing okay, but the cursor stays invisible.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to http://www.mozillazine.org/forums/index.php?c=4 2. Choose a topic (e.g. Phoenix General) 3. Press "New Topic" 4. Type something in the main input box 5. Go to Help/About Phoenix 6. Close the About Phoenix dialog 7. Resume typing in the same input box. Actual Results: You can continue typing, but the cursor does not show up.
Expected Results: The cursor should become visible in the original input box.
Possible dupe of bug #188457?
reproducable Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.3a) Gecko/20030110 Phoenix/0.5. it works with any textarea including the one im typing in now (additional comments).

Is this Linux or Windows? Please ensure that the UA and build ID correspond to one another when filing a bug.
I know what it is going on here but the behaviour is slightly different between the two OSes yet results from the same thing.
In Linux, the cursor is there but won't respond to arrow keys or end/home, as I am getting it right now!!!!! aarrgh!. Typing text though is apparently unaffected.
This is possibly a dupe of bug #188457, but I can't quite follow what has been reported there, plus the UA/ID is even more whacked out than this one.
A workaround is to send the window to the taskbar and reactivate it.
-->Confirmed -->All OS
this worksforme in builds from this morning.
i can still reproduce this bug with the February 1 nightly on winXP
Can still see it on latest (Feb 2nd) build on w2k. I experience it randomly. -> Reopening.
Back to WORKSFORME, since the bug seems to have disappeared for a while.

bug.short_desc: [rfe] icon set for Phoenix

thank you for your attention Francesco De Francesco

Francesco De Francesco

Ugh... The question we should ask ourselves is: Do we really want a red duck and not a phoenix icon?
Anyway, this discussion shouldn't be held in a bug report. If you have an icon set proposal, e-mail mozilla-phoenix@mozilla.org, just as the release notes says.
Another note: You shouldn't set the target milestone for your reported bugs. That's for the assignee to do.
